reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s percentile-based definition/normalization of “best feasible future” (99.99th percentile) and claims the resulting “eutopia is hard” conclusion is largely an artifact of this choice, especially in fat-tailed/high-variance outcome spaces. This is relevant but not fully central: much of the essay’s core case for “no easy eutopia” comes from substantive claims about value fragility, many independent moral ‘failure modes,’ multiplicative-factor modeling, and especially the later argument that many plausible moral views are intrinsically fussy (linear/unbounded, bounded-but-approximately-linear, separate aggregation with tiny bads, etc.). Those arguments don’t primarily rely on percentile normalization; the percentile is mainly a convenient scaling to [0,1]. Still, the critique would weaken some rhetorical/quantitative comparisons (e.g., “60–40 gamble vs wonderful futures,” thresholding at 0.5/0.9) and any inference that rarity is demonstrated rather than stipulated by the benchmark.

Strength is moderate-low: it’s true that choosing an extreme percentile as ‘1’ can make intermediate percentiles look small under heavy tails and that this can manufacture large ratios. But the paper’s key target is probability mass above fixed fractions of the top outcome (0.5, 0.9) rather than gaps between percentiles per se, and their later fussiness arguments aim to show that (under many moral views) near-best requires specific resource use / near-zero bads regardless of the percentile scaling. So the critique does not “nearly automatically” generate the main conclusion, though it does expose a genuine risk of conflating a normalization choice with an empirical claim about how disappointing typical futures are.

Correctness is fairly high but not perfect: the point about percentile normalization interacting with fat tails is broadly correct; the claim that the conclusion is essentially an artifact is overstated given the paper’s independent substantive premises. Clarity is high and dead weight is minimal. It cleanly focuses on a single methodological issue. Overall, it’s a useful methodological caution but not a devastating objection to the full position.
title: Percentile-based benchmarks make fragility an artifact of definition
